Review: I upgraded my device with the option to trade in - this was for the value of ¬£400.I was under the assumption that the ¬£400 credit would be applied to my account and I would pay my bill as usual. I called Vodafone and they advised that the credit could not be applied to my current bill, but I could use it on the next one. Meaning I would be ¬£400 down for a month. I am not really in a position to be able to do this, which is why I traded in the old device. I called Vodafone and asked if this could be refunded to my bank account if I made the payment - I was advised it could be. I hesitated paying this, as it would (and now has) put me in a difficult financial situation - I cannot be without broadband and mobile as I work from home, so today I paid the bill.I called Vodafone to ask about this credit being returned to me, and honestly feel like my intelligence is being questioned.. The agent I spoke to (Loretta) was very helpful, but told me initially that it owuldn't be possible to have the credit paid out to me as "it is still accruing in the account, and is currently only at ¬£393.." this makes absolutely no sense. Loretta went away to speak to some other team and came back and said that it would not be possible as that credit has not been "allocated".. even though I can see in a big green box that I have ¬£400 credit. I then asked Loretta if I could then just have the ¬£393, if that is what has "accrued". She went away again to speak to another team for quite a while and then came back to tell me this is not possible and I would have to wait until the next billing cycle. I then asked Loretta if she could confirm that that account credit would still be available when my next bill is issued, rather than being used to pay the bill and she said "No, we will deduct the billed amount before sending the funds"I really feel like my intelligence is being insulted.. the account credit is there, it is not "accruing" - the device I traded in was a whole device, I didn't send it piece by piece so it makes no sense that the credit would "accrue". I understand that companies want to do as much as they can to not have to transfer funds out, but I was told that this was possible, without any caveats about the credit needing to accrue, or be allocated (it clearly has been allocated as I can see available credit within my app to be used!Please either arrange for a refund or return my device. I then reconnect to yet another agent!I reconnect to another agent and speak to him for an hour, switching, unplugging, resetting, updating etc then get disconnected again as I am relying on mobile data!I rejoin the queue and chat to agent no 3, really loosing hope now! Of course it doesn't make any difference and they transfer me to a manager. Review: FTTP Broadband from Vodafone:I've just had a truly dreadful experience with Vodafone and thought I would warn others.My 1.6Gbps FTTP service was installed yesterday at the second attempt (8 days after it should have been). The service worked at the advertised speeds getting 1.6Gbps during the day and being throttled to their 'guaranteed minimum' 800Mbps later in the evening and through midnight and beyond.The issue is that the supplied Ultra Hub only has 1 x 2.5Gbps port (which is used for the ONT incoming fibre connection) and 4 x 1Gbps ports which obviously can't supply the 1.6Gbps I paid for to my wired 10Gbps intranet and BE85 WiFi7 mesh system.As I'm only on day 2 of the 'cooling off period' I tried to get Vodafone to simply swap the Router for the one they now include in the exact same 1.6Gbps package. Should have been easy, Right? Wrong! Chat to AI bot and then Agent last night got me nothing except 'call a number tomorrow'. I did. The first agent at least tried to be helpful but couldn't do what was needed. The second agent in termination/retentions frankly couldn't give a damn so I simply terminated the contract.I've now ordered a 1.6Gbps service from EE (who also guarantee a minimum 1.3Gbps which is much better than Vodafone's 800 minimum!).I only need a Hub that works and feeds into my existing intranet so customer service should not be needed (I've heard that EE aren't great either).I would now have to suggest very strongly that people avoid Vodafone based on my experience (as a pre-existing broadband user). I didn't have any problems with them before, but they failed me with what should have been a very simple replacement task.Obviously this speed issue only applies to plans above 1 Gbps, but I would also add that it was impossible to get the supplied WiFi Extender to pair, and I'm a computer geek having worked in the industry all my life. The pairing issue is apparently very common. Caveat Emptor!Edit: I reached out to Vodafone via Facebook messaging as requested in their response, went through the exact same process I'd previously already gone through 3 times today, and eventually got told to phone another landline number for an IMMEDIATE disconnect! I had requested Saturday midnight. Talk about adding insult to injury. I can only think they are trying to force me beyond the 14 day no cancellation fee deadline.Please note right here that I tried to cancel this 4 times today May 20th 2025 and I expect that request to be honored and no early termination fee charged!I was also unable to raise a formal complaint, but told the details for that were on their website!
